title_review: Excellent restaurant for location, food quality and service
review_preview: The title sums up the qualities of this restaurant bistro pretty well! What is missing in the description is the very affordable price for the experience compared to Madrid standards.My family and I had a great dinner last night. Service was so personal, rightly...
review_full: The title sums up the qualities of this restaurant bistro pretty well! What is missing in the description is the very affordable price for the experience compared to Madrid standards. My family and I had a great dinner last night. Service was so personal, rightly paced and warm. The interior is cosy Spanish. There are few tables, so I suggest to book one beforehand. Both fish and meat dishes and tapas were very well cooked and tasty. Cheeses are also extremely nice.  What differentiates this Spanish restaurant from other traditional ones in Madrid is that their menu has also Asian influences in some of their food proposals. And they are all cooked super well. The International tapas are so good, for instance. Dont miss them if you go!

review_preview: In our 4 days in Madrid, we ate here twice for dinner.  It was THAT good! We had shrimp (gambones) in a yummy sauce for 10.50‚Ç¨ and a small musaka for 3‚Ç¨. But our absolute favourites were the pork chops in a tasty sauce with...
review_full: In our 4 days in Madrid, we ate here twice for dinner. It was THAT good! We had shrimp (gambones) in a yummy sauce for 10.50‚Ç¨ and a small musaka for 3‚Ç¨. But our absolute favourites were the pork chops in a tasty sauce with potatoes (Solomillo Sur) and the shredded braised beef (ropa vieja) in the best sauce I've ever tasted. We used bread to soak it all up. Both dishes were available in half portions, as most of their dishes are as well. It allowed us to taste many varieties of tapas. My son enjoyed the salmon skewer with melted cheese on top. On our 2nd visit we noticed the board on the wall with daily specials so we ordered fish (9‚Ç¨) that came with mashed potatoes flavoured with broccoli which doesn't sound good, but was incredibly, surprisingly delicious. We also loved the paella which wasn't served in a traditional pan (so no crispy bottom) but was still excellent because of the sauce on it and the shrimp, baby octopus, fish and meat on it, 9‚Ç¨. Other highlights included the sangria 3‚Ç¨ with tons of fruit inside. We loved the red velvet cake (one of the best I've ever had). Sadly on our 2nd visit, they didn't have any more. We tried the strawberry cheesecake (4‚Ç¨) and while it was tasty, it didn't wow us as much as the red velvet did. Finally, I need to mention the exceptional service. Alex was the main person who helped us. His English is excellent and he is very welcoming. We also had another waitress (I didn't catch her name) whom my kids also loved. She spoke very good English and was so nice to us. We were greeted like old friends and given very good suggestions on what to order. My kids were given a little glass dish of gummy candies for dessert, I was given a free shot of wildberry liquor after dinner. Final points I forgot to add - bread was free here (you'll need it to soak up the amazing sauces) and they have English menus. Washroom (WC) was clean. So between the outstanding food and even better staff, this was the best dining experience we had in Madrid. I highly recommend that you visit and I'm not surprised they are ranked so high on tripadvisor.

title_review: Popular for reinventing locally famous spanish dishes.
review_preview: We are a team of young American culinary professionals from Texas with a passion for food, culture, and excitement; our love for food has driven us to work towards developing a greater understanding of food while looking into the history, culture, traditions, and techniques behind...
review_full: We are a team of young American culinary professionals from Texas with a passion for food, culture, and excitement; our love for food has driven us to work towards developing a greater understanding of food while looking into the history, culture, traditions, and techniques behind each dish. Our company is called Culinary Crossings and we are traveling the world, to discover and try new flavors, while documenting, and experiencing other cultures & their cuisines. During the summer we had the opportunity of traveling to 28 different countries and over 100 restaurants throughout Europe over a span of 3 months interviewing restaurant owners, cooking with chefs and tasting traditional yet popular dishes native to the region.  We visited a restaurant in Madrid, Spain that not only specialized in creating local famous dishes but reinventing new ones so that guests get a unique dining experience after every visit. We were shown how to make saut√©ed squid with green beans and and balsamic reduction. Cod croquettes. And seared tuna with balsamic and sesame oil. Even though there was a slight language barrier when it came to sitting down with the chef and owner of the restaurant, no conversation was needed as the delicious dishes in front of us spoke for themselves. Not only was the taste and presentation of these dishes spectacular, the delightful ambiance was the icing on the cake during our visit to Taberna Rayuela.

title_review: Yummy inventive take on spanish tapas
review_preview: First they welcome you with wonderful olives and salted almonds. All of the dishes we tried were excellent. You can order a big plate or a tapa sized one, which allowed us to try several of the menu options.  We especially liked the Morcilla de...
review_full: First they welcome you with wonderful olives and salted almonds. All of the dishes we tried were excellent. You can order a big plate or a tapa sized one, which allowed us to try several of the menu options. We especially liked the Morcilla de Burgos and the salad was exquisite with 2 types of cheese, walnuts, beets, assortment of spinach, lettuce, arugula, endive and apple perfectly seasoned with honey dressing. The meat and cheese plate was exquisite (hand-cut really good jamon de bellota included). We ordered 4 tapas, a salad, the meat and cheese plate, 2 glasses of wine and water came to 40 EUR per person. And we were so full we couldn't go for dessert... The ambience is also tasteful and the service very attentive. I would go back in a heartbeat. All their dishes looked amazing and the quality of the ingredients they used was superb.

title_review: Great food and atmosphere at any time of the day
review_preview: Last time I was here with friends for lunch, but I must say that any ocassion is good at this place: lunch, dinner, coffee & cake (they have delicious home-made pies) or late night gin tonic.The place is birught and spacious, stylefully decorated and...
review_full: Last time I was here with friends for lunch, but I must say that any ocassion is good at this place: lunch, dinner, coffee & cake (they have delicious home-made pies) or late night gin tonic. The place is birught and spacious, stylefully decorated and has unique views at the Viaducto. It is two steps away from the Royal Palace and Cathedral, located opposite the Vistillas (where are festivals in May and August). The atmosphere is relaxed and familiar. The owners and staff are very friendly. The food is excellent, a fusion between traditional Spanish and Belgian with the personal touch of chef Nicolas. During the week there is a nice lunch menu for a fixed price with choice between 3 starters and 3 main dishes including a drink and dessert or coffee. The a la carte menu has more variety. There are tapas (to share) as well as starters and main dishes.

review_preview: Stopped in on a late Saturday afternoon after visiting el Prado. Alex, the server, was fantastic. This place had a modern twist on classic Spanish dishes as well as some non-Spanish dishes.  For example, the patatas bravas were not fried, so a bit healthier than...
review_full: Stopped in on a late Saturday afternoon after visiting el Prado. Alex, the server, was fantastic. This place had a modern twist on classic Spanish dishes as well as some non-Spanish dishes. For example, the patatas bravas were not fried, so a bit healthier than normal.  We split the following: - Salmorejo (amazing and super garlicky) - Salad el Sur (simple but good) - Patatas bravas (decent) - Mushroom risotto (special of the day) - Ropa vieja (mind-blowingly good - a Cuban might say it isn't traditional ropa but it was so so good my wife and I were having trouble sharing it) The only thing we found a little underwhelming and wasn't a big deal was the chips served with the ropa were soggy. That didn't detract from how good the rest of the meal was as well as the great service.  We seemed to be the only tourists in there and had a cool local feel as it is on a small side street. However, we were welcomed. I would definitely go there again.

review_preview: We found this place through trip advisor and wanted somewhere good for a family and a vegetarian. The restaurant is small and cosy and was fairly quiet on the Monday evening we visited. The staff were very friendly and welcoming despite us not speaking any...
review_full: We found this place through trip advisor and wanted somewhere good for a family and a vegetarian. The restaurant is small and cosy and was fairly quiet on the Monday evening we visited. The staff were very friendly and welcoming despite us not speaking any Spanish. There was a varied menu to suit all tastes. The food was tasty and well presented. The portions were a good size with an option for a full or half portion. I would definitely say this place is worth a visit if you want good,tasty, traditional food at a very reasonable price and cosy and informal setting. It is family friendly too but I would also say it is good for couples or with friends.  Definitely our favourite place on our trip to Madrid.

review_preview: We spent a weekend in Madrid and tried a few different restaurants that we happened to be walking past and found them all to be disappointing - clearly aimed at tourists and overpriced. Fortunately we learned the error of our ways and looked up a...
review_full: We spent a weekend in Madrid and tried a few different restaurants that we happened to be walking past and found them all to be disappointing - clearly aimed at tourists and overpriced. Fortunately we learned the error of our ways and looked up a place on Tripadvisor - one that isn't directly on a main road. This small restaurant is located on an inconspicuous side street, but is well worth seeking out if you want a proper Spanish restaurant experience.  The hosts were really friendly and welcoming, the food was great - distinctly Spanish but not simply the stereotypical tourist-friendly dishes, and very good value. The place was packed with locals, and has a great buzz to it.  Take a quick detour from the tourist spots and eat here!

review_preview: Just back from an amazing dining extravaganza at the One Michelin Starred Club Allard here in Madrid.  It‚Äôs located in an historic building full of antiques, with soaring ceilings, oozing with charm.  We began our adventure with rose champagne and they provided the first of...
review_full: Just back from an amazing dining extravaganza at the One Michelin Starred Club Allard here in Madrid. It‚Äôs located in an historic building full of antiques, with soaring ceilings, oozing with charm. We began our adventure with rose champagne and they provided the first of many amuse -bouches. This one highlighted cod crisps with herb and seaweed accoutrements. They also provided an additional treat, served on a sculpture that simulated the symbol of Madrid; a bear eating the fruit from the Madrono tree. These delectables included a cod ball, a warm, liquid, lightly encrusted ham and cheese ball, and a sandwich of squid. All a pure delight!  Our sommelier and exquisite entertainer for the evening, Alboro, helped us select a lovely white; a Rioja, Que Bonito Casa Reaba. It was a full bodied white that reminded us of a Chassagne Montrachet. It held up perfectly with all the courses to come. This restaurant offers several tasting menus to suit the seasons and freshest ingredients available. What is also really accessible is there are ala carte offerings. You may choose half portions or whole portions, mixing and matching as you like. After discussing portion sizes, we ended up selecting two half portion starters and two half portion entrees. We chose the Gastronomia 2012 Bollota ham  which was perfect with the crusty bread and olive oil from the south of Spain. This was followed by a second half portion appetizer of Andignac foie gras medallion with duck juice and citric. AMAZING! This was also paired with a black truffle brioche dinner roll. The combination was perfection.  Proceeding onto our first half entree, we chose the turbot, served on a bed of samphire greens and spinach, with a fumet and toasted corn reduction. We chased this delight with a sake infused with a reduced fish bone elixir. Quite special and unusual. Turbot is always a treat if not over-cooked and this was among the best we have ever had.  What followed was a real surprise. Alboro asked us to join him upstairs, just off the kitchen. He shared two glasses of a fine dry sherry with us until Batiste, assistant chef, joined us in this circular room with a table prepped with an array of ingredients.  He served daikon two ways augmented with Japanese spices, seaweed and wasabi. Then, we sampled Spanish beef that had been dry aged and then marinated in miso for additional time. The final product was very ‚Äúwagyu‚Äù like and delicious. What a special treat!  Our second half entree was Wild Roe deer loin. It was served with pineapple, mint and salsify. Cooked to perfection and quite remarkable.  We opted not to select a dessert from the menu, but the dessert cart of complimentary elegant sweets made an appearance anyway. You can‚Äôt go wrong! Fruits, chocolate confections, petit fours, gelees, and an amazing tiramisu with manchego could not be resisted. Alboro also helped us select a marvelous dessert wine ( Molino Real Mountain wine from Malaga) and shared another favorite of his from Tenerife ( Vinatigo Malvasia Aromatica Clasico) in the Canary Islands.  Thanks to the whole team that made this such a delightful evening for us! Special kudos to Alboro, Miguel and Batiste!

title_review: Showmanship, Exacting Service, Kind and Friendly
review_preview: We looked for many resturants to have a special dinner at during our trip to Spain and we are supremely happy we found Club Allard. The building outdoors is beautiful, (once construction is done in 2021 on Plaza de Espana an absolutely premier location but...
review_full: We looked for many resturants to have a special dinner at during our trip to Spain and we are supremely happy we found Club Allard. The building outdoors is beautiful, (once construction is done in 2021 on Plaza de Espana an absolutely premier location but did not hurt the experience).   We arrived for our reservation with 2 other parties at opening time...9pm...late for us but normal for the Spanish. They obviosuly knew we were American and gave us our menu translated best as possible into English. (I am paying particular attention to this part of the review because I saw many negative comments on Trip Advisor about them not speaking English, sadly some forget they are in Spain.) They also asked if we preferred English or Spanish, we opted for them to speak to us in Spanish until we ask a question. The night contiued in "Spanglish" between us the servers, Maitre, and tableside cooks, a couple times they immediately went to English and then started over in Spanish after remembering our request. Quite fun. Wine list was extensive, and once we nearly finished our bottle the Maitre brought over a few more glasses of wine for us to try and decide what we liked to pair with final few coures. The night had started with a complimentary champage, and amuse bouche. Night finished with 3 courses of dessert and digestif. In between there were 3 tableside cooking presenations and the most unique presentation of a mussel cooked inside of a sour dough mini loaf. How did they even come up with that?  Alvaro the F&B director spent time at all of the tables and quite a bit with us. He walked us out to the cab back to our hotel and even gave us recommendations of restaurants in other cities wed be visiting. I could continue on but honestly no need, if in Madrid worth the investment on yourself.

In general, however, it is a place we will visit again with a hope to see the past creativety in taste, texture, and presentation.

review_preview: While staying in Madrid, we had the pleasure to eat here twice.  Hey, when you find great salmon tartar AND steak tartar, you don't mess around. Both times, the staff was fun and got it right.  And, the tartars were just SO tasty, especially the...
review_full: While staying in Madrid, we had the pleasure to eat here twice. Hey, when you find great salmon tartar AND steak tartar, you don't mess around. Both times, the staff was fun and got it right. And, the tartars were just SO tasty, especially the salmon. We also ordered an appetizer of a local ham, complexly cured (well, all of the hams in Spain. Wow! Not an expert, but this was very, very good.), a house salad - large enough to share with 4, and 2 orders of their mussels. Ah, the mussels: cooked just the right length of time and in a wine sauce that we greedily sopped up with bread.  Pigged all of this, and then suicided in the desserts, getting the creme brulee, the cheese cake, and the postre of the day. 2 bottles of wine, so had coffees to sober up (didn't work). Wiser, and sans our Dutch friends, we had the salmon tartar, a salad, and a bottle of wine (1), the second time. No desserts, still living on the fumes of the previous debauch. Good time, great staff, fairly quiet, no TV where we sat. Lovely, just lovely, with just enough teasing by the staff to give you a feeling of really being wanted.

review_full: We saw an 8pm show at the Teatro Galileo and wanted somewhere to grab dinner after. Thought I thought 10:30 wouldn't be too far on the later end for a Spanish dinner, we were practically the only people in the place (granted, it was a Wednesday). The decor is nothing to marvel at, but the service was good, as was the food. We shared the spiced carrot hummus to start, which was very well seasoned, and I had some surprisingly delicious curry meatballs. While the decor and the menu are both a little all over the place and it's certainly not in a heavily trafficked area, I'd recommend Tres Bocas if you're nearby.

Menu might not look much in the respect as the items are not described and it looks limited at first glance, BUT IT IS NOT! Next time though!

review_full: We booked a table at Taverna el Sur based on Trip Advisor recommendations. When we arrived there (at 8 o'clock which is way to early for Madrid) we were a bit disappointed and actually left the place on our way to making the biggest mistake of the evening. We went back inside and did not regret anything. We were a party of four and had the garlic prawns (above average) and the Solomillo Sur (pork with a very nice sauce) which was a great to our taste. On top of that we had two carafa of the best Sangria we tried in Madrid and the cheesecake desert topped our experience with an explosion of flavours.  Perfect place for a dinner in a very relaxed atmosphere.

review_preview: After the first night of really great food at a very nice price we were back at it.  I must correct my previous post, I had beef cheeks the first night not pig cheeks.  The next two nights were as good as the first.  I...
review_full: After the first night of really great food at a very nice price we were back at it. I must correct my previous post, I had beef cheeks the first night not pig cheeks. The next two nights were as good as the first. I had three tapas which were very diverse, Spanish and International, and delicious. My wife had a hamberguese. This menu covers all the bases.  Another night we had salads. Now maybe these salads were to be shared, we didn't. I had a delightful tomato and buffalo mozzarella salad with balsamic vinegar. It was huge. Sally had a Caesar salad with chicken. We spent six weeks in northern Spain landing in and departing from Madrid. We had some very nice food in those six weeks. But this was a great way to end the trip. It is as if we saved the best for last. How they offered such a diverse menu at these reasonable prices I don't understand. Because I don't know about reservations or group meeting availability at Rayuelas I can't comment and I am afraid this will hold down the rating for this place. It is a '5' for a couple wanting good food. Very convenient location if you are near the Palacio Real or La Latina. wayne iNWI

review_full: After a horrible meal at a fake Italian restaurant in Santiago where we paid too much for factory food, we tried the restaurant below our rented apartment in Madrid. What a nice find. I had pig cheeks for the second time on the trip. this time in a nice red wine sauce with thyme. Partnered with creamed sweet potato. My wife had a Moroccan chicken and almond pie. It was chicken and almonds with mild spices under a filo dough crust sprinkled with powered sugar. She was in heaven. Good wine as expected. Nice staff. Menu translated into English,which was a plus. We will go Back. Sally has a second selection already picked. Additionally, for the first time in our five and a half week Spain trip she had a women's bathroom with toilet paper, hand towels, soap, and HOT water. I called it 'the trifecta'. Romantic setting around the corner south of the basilica of the royal palace. real nice job.Very happy wayne iNESP

review_preview: Very often when travelling you stick to what's suggested in a guide book. As they say places change and new places open up. Well, this is one of those places that has opened in the last year. A feast of tapas, both national and international....
review_full: Very often when travelling you stick to what's suggested in a guide book. As they say places change and new places open up. Well, this is one of those places that has opened in the last year. A feast of tapas, both national and international. Well priced, particualrly given it's proximity to the Royal Palace and Cathedral of the Almudena. Just cross the Segovia Viaduct (left-hand side as you leave the Cathedral behind you) and take the first left. The staff are great and will suggest dishes of the day. If you're going for a siesta before more sightseeing, break open a bottle of Ribas del C√∫a, a wine make by a small company run by women in the Bierzo region of Le√≥n. You can taste the difference! If you a sightseeingholic, book your table for dinner and have two bottles! Don't miss these two things, you'll quickly come to see there's more to Spain than Flamenco!

title_review: Good service, good food, relaxing experience.

review_full: We were recommended this place by another restaurant as they were full. This place was quiet but this was preferable for us having had a long day and just wanting to have a relaxed unhurried meal. This is exactly what this place seems to offer- the interior is relaxed and welcoming as is the service.¬† Both waiters who served us spoke some English and were both friendly and very attentive. The food was tasty, we ordered a selection of hot Tapas on a sharing plate between us plus bread which was just enough allowing us room to try the cheesecake for dessert which was delicious and a nice end to the meal. The prices were reasonable considering we had several drinks. I enjoyed our experience here and would recommend it to anyone in the area looking for a quiet, pleasant and relaxed meal.

review_preview: It has been a very enjoyable visit. The food was delicious, everything with a little twist. We had a salad for starters, my boyfriend usually complains that salads are too simple to order in a restaurant but this one was totally worth it. The gnocchis...
review_full: It has been a very enjoyable visit. The food was delicious, everything with a little twist. We had a salad for starters, my boyfriend usually complains that salads are too simple to order in a restaurant but this one was totally worth it. The gnocchis seemed homemade (which seems to be rare these days), served with a creamy but yet light sauce and perfectly cooked asparagus. Also, i appreciate a vegetarian option in a Spanish restaurant, it doesn't always happen.  The service very attentive and quick too. The place itself is very cool, i really want to go back for cocktails on those comfortable couches! To give some constructive criticism: the bread was quite dry, i would like some fresh bread to go with such a good meal. Also, they charge a service charge (1‚Ç¨) which isn't much but it still annoys me a bit since it's not really usual in other restaurants in Madrid. Probably i would be on a better mood if that charge was included in the food prices.

title_review: Lovely place with awesome traditional food
review_preview: This place is located in the residential neighbourhood of Carabanchel. It is actually a bit hidden and far from the city centre, but if you have the chance you should come to this place. The food is so delicious. They are specialized in roasted pork...
review_full: This place is located in the residential neighbourhood of Carabanchel. It is actually a bit hidden and far from the city centre, but if you have the chance you should come to this place. The food is so delicious. They are specialized in roasted pork and lamb. These are very traditional Spanish dishes. You will find it in many places in Madrid, but here they are really good quality and at a reasonable price.  I especially recommend the roasted baby pork or "cochinillo". It is advisable to book it in advance. They might run out of them if you don't make a reservation.  The service is really kind and the place has a great atmosphere. A big dinning room with many tables and people having lively conversations while eating their food. It's the typical places where Spanish families go for weekend lunch or dinner.

review_preview: We were staying nearby and after a long day of walking could not face another treck. So, we did what everybody does and turned to Tripadvisor to find recommendations of restaurants nearby. The one‚Äôs for Havana Blues were positive and we decided to give it...
review_full: We were staying nearby and after a long day of walking could not face another treck. So, we did what everybody does and turned to Tripadvisor to find recommendations of restaurants nearby. The one‚Äôs for Havana Blues were positive and we decided to give it a try. In these days of flashy chic and sophistication, it is a real joy to find somewhere that has things of equal value, such as pride of the business developed and nurtured; of having people to dine as a guest instead of just another punter; of taking joy in knowing that the food provided is good quality and home-made; of being proud to belong to their country and in the good things it produces. All these were in abundance at Havana Blues. We were treated to a warm welcome and made to feel as though we were wanted guests to a humble establishment. I immediately got into the Cuban spirit and asked if I could try a good rum. My eagerness to try the Cuban national drink was rewarded by the owner enthusiastically wanting me to try his recommended rum. Nothing pretentious as a coxtail, simply a choice of with ice or without. And boy was it a good. Rather like having a very good singly malt whiskey, a drink with which I am much more familiar. My exposure to rum is limited and so I did not have a bench-mark with which to reference it, but I can say it was deliciously smooth and much more drinkable on its own, than say, Captain Morgan‚Äôs or Bacardi. It was a delicious drink. I now need find somewhere I can get some for myself!   The food was a treat. I had a lamb casserole with a special rice. Delicious. My wife and I shared a homemade cheesecake, again, which was lovely.   If you want flashy surroundings or authentic Spanish cuisine, go elsewhere. If you want something slightly different and are willing to forego prime location, then this is the place for you. The meal we had was more than just the sum of its parts; it was the whole thing put together by an owner who wanted to serve his customers and give them a good dining experience supported by good quality food. A real pleasure and I have no trouble in recommending this restaurant.

review_full: We throughly enjoyed our dining experience at Verdejo with our college aged children and niece during our stay in Madrid. As others have noted, it‚Äôs a tiny restaurant with six or seven tables, which allows the owners and staff to mingle and talk through their dishes with their diners.  Our niece is adverse to fish and sea food so we focused on the meat with feet part of their menu. The Escabeche with the wild boar and the steak tartare were exceptionally made dishes and the sweet breads were the hit of the evening. You can order full and half sized portions, so the menu is geared towards sharing and trying different items. We are planning to go back to Madrid just so we can try the seafood portion of their menu.  Their wine list wasn‚Äôt extensive, but the selections were solid and reasonable, especially if you like Spanish reds.  All in all, a very memorable meal in a week of good eating in Madrid.

review_preview: On our last full day in Madrid, my wife and I had dinner at this restaurant in the heart of Madrid. This restaurant has very comfortable seating with an excellent staff and delicious food. By the time our journey through Spain had brought us to...
review_full: On our last full day in Madrid, my wife and I had dinner at this restaurant in the heart of Madrid. This restaurant has very comfortable seating with an excellent staff and delicious food. By the time our journey through Spain had brought us to Madrid, my wife and I were getting used to the late dinners as compared to our usual (much earlier!) dinner time. This allowed us to enjoy the variety of dinner offerings at Cinco Jotas Serrano. The meal started with a generous and fresh garden salad served with a tasty roll. I then sampled a couple of slices of the Jamon Iberico which spoiled me during my time in Spain. Next up was a slice of the traditional ‚ÄúSpanish omelet‚Äù which was fluffy, rich and could almost be a meal in itself. This was served with excellent croquettes. For my entr√©e I had a perfectly braised slice of pork loin served with roasted potatoes. Even though I am not a big meat eater, I decided to try something other than fish and was very impressed with this pork loin. The meal ended with a slice of cheesecake. It was very good‚Äîa bit lighter than the ‚ÄúNew York style‚Äù cheesecake that I am used to. It was a perfect complement to the filling dinner. I quite enjoyed my dinner at this restaurant which highlighted some of the culinary treats I fell in love with during my journey around Spain.

review_preview: One Saturday night, my young friends demanded that we go out to dinner. It was a late hour, even for Madrid.We strolled down Calle de Lagasca searching for a certain place one of them had seen in passing once, and take note of. It...
review_full: One Saturday night, my young friends demanded that we go out to dinner. It was a late hour, even for Madrid. We strolled down Calle de Lagasca searching for a certain place one of them had seen in passing once, and take note of. It was Amparito Roca, still open and full of happy people. 'A theme blending music and literature,' I thought, 'what could be better for a musician writing stories in Madrid?' It evoked to me the charm of Les Bouquinistes on Paris' Left Bank. The staff were winding down for the night, but nevertheless welcomed us to wait a few moments until a table became free. During that time the chef himself engaged with one of my charming associates to devise an improvised array of dishes for us - based not just on the menu, but what we liked. The parade of courses were served personally by their author, and were each in turn a delight - right up to the cheese tray which featured a fruit paste that was a mystery to me. But the palate is able to transport one through a morsel's lineage to basic forms before infusions of sugar and other flavors, before cooking, back to to its elemental - even astringent? - reincarnation. As the paste itself dissolved into oblivion, it dawned on me...quince. This paste, Membrillo, I later learned, is quite universal in Spain, and the cheese had likely been a Manchego Viejo (mature Manchego) with its distinctive texture and rind. The two are commonly paired. With the sole exception of this quince paste and the cleverly engineered citric "caviar" which brightened the tuna tartare, every dish represented a handful of lovely fresh ingredients elevated to art. The chef, of course, was Jesus Velasco, of virtuoso simplicity and as it turns, renown to the Madrid restaurant scene. I thank him for imparting the secret of Jamon etiquette to this accidental wanderer, and his kind attention to our boisterous company. Perhaps the first visit to Amparito Roca was by lucky chance. The next will be by design.

title_review: Let Marian & Carmen Pamper your Palate
review_preview: Sublime is a word I'm yet to use in any of my reviews. Yet, for this tiny culinary enclave in Madrid it is just the right expression. Having been to a few top notch, Michelim starred restaurants in Spain, I can tell you without any...
review_full: Sublime is a word I'm yet to use in any of my reviews. Yet, for this tiny culinary enclave in Madrid it is just the right expression. Having been to a few top notch, Michelim starred restaurants in Spain, I can tell you without any hesitation that Taberna Artesana Verdejo Madrid is right there with the best,if not the best (with the only exception of Diverxo - which is something out of this planet in of it self). Verdejo's cuisine is authentic. With a lot of character. Try the Escabeche de Jabali, or the Sepia and babh shark (cazon) meat balls, and ask Marian to pair your meal with whatever wine she may have in mind. Verdejo boasts one of the best Sherry selections I've ever seen. This is a place you will never regret visiting. Verdejo is true. And carmen and Marian are simply the best. No need to show off, just be yourself. Nothing else beats the true. If you really are to experience authenticity and happines, come to Verdejo and surrender to the taste

Indeed a great option for lunch or dinner.

title_review: Great Thai food at a reasonable price
review_preview: Was in Madrid for a long weekend, mainly because 2 German friends were there at the same time for their first visit to Madrid. So I was mainly their as "tour guide". We all love good food and good restaurants.As most of the restaurants...
review_full: Was in Madrid for a long weekend, mainly because 2 German friends were there at the same time for their first visit to Madrid. So I was mainly their as "tour guide". We all love good food and good restaurants. As most of the restaurants I used to go to in the Cheuca area have now closed since my last visit, I decided to try Bambubox on the Friday for the "Menu del dia" lunch. Had spring rolls to start with, which were very tasty and not like a lot of places which serve quite greasy ones. These were "dry", and with a nice dip. I had a main course of Thai red chicken curry, which had a great "zing" of chilli. Usually for Spanish tastes, Thai restaurants in Spain often tone down the chilli and other hot spices. With a glass of decent white wine and a mineral water, the bill was 14euros - great value for money I think. As I had enjoyed it so much, went back again on the Sunday evening with my friends, and we had another great meal.

Having lived in the UK for many years where we have an abundance of Thai restaurants even in smaller cities, Madrid is missing a trick here . Not all locals want tapas & chuleton every time they dine out. We opted to choose the degustaci√≥n menu for 2 which offers 3 different types of curries - green Thai, yellow prawn & red beef with a bowl of steamed rice of ‚Ç¨30,00. A little on the steep side of pricing I'd admit, but the food was tasty, hot, presentable and we were left satisfied. For an extra ‚Ç¨14,00 based on 2 people sharing they offer a selection of starters to the mains that we had too if your hungrier. It's in a great location too for tourists and locals like near Gran Via in the neighbourhood of Chueca.

title_review: If you love Thai food this place will break your heart
review_preview: We had a romantic meal for two on a Wednesday night. We were staying in a hotel in the area and picked up the place following Tripavisor reviews. We ordered Poh Pla Sod as a started; these were a type of spring rolls which were...
review_full: We had a romantic meal for two on a Wednesday night. We were staying in a hotel in the area and picked up the place following Tripavisor reviews. We ordered Poh Pla Sod as a started; these were a type of spring rolls which were basically cabbage and orange with little other flavorings; texture was not great either, a little crunchy and a little chewy. The waiter made recommendations and we changed our two initial choices for the main courses. The Chicken with Holy Basil was disappointed; presentation was unattractive, looking like a scramble of minced things; flavor was flat, just sweet and a little acidic; there was no umami, sourness or spice punch. The Pad Thai was just sticky rice ribbons closer to spaghetti bolognese than to Thai cooking and not very pleasant; I like my food and I just could not finish it. The decoration is modern and pleasant, so is the music played in the background. The service is also fine, although they failed miserably with the recommendations. I left the place wondering if they used us to get rid of the old stuff in the kitchen.  In summary, if you love Thai food or are looking for an introduction to the incredible cooking of South-East Asia, try some where else; you will not fall in love here.

title_review: Re: Can't stop talking about it!
review_preview: I have several foodie friends whom I respect and treasure as trustworthy sources to provide balanced and nuanced restaurant recommendations; this restaurant has been on the top of their list for some time now.There are enough reviews to get an idea of what the...
review_full: I have several foodie friends whom I respect and treasure as trustworthy sources to provide balanced and nuanced restaurant recommendations; this restaurant has been on the top of their list for some time now. There are enough reviews to get an idea of what the place exudes and achieves, so I won't bore you with that description. I prefer to get to the best part: what we found strikingly delicious: 1. Gunkan Vieras - the subtle flavors so delicately balanced provide a delicious start to the food road show 2. 1/2 Rac Mar Montana - the sea/mountain taste-scape curiously starts on your pallet with the sea followed by a robust shot of mountain meat. 3. 1/2 Rac Roll Cangrejo - the crab meat, it's texture and distinct flavor, provide one of the most delicious and stripped down dishes on the menu. We also enjoyed trying the French and South African red wines on the menu. The service was attentive and knowledgeable, especially in regards to how to organize the plethora of dishes you will inevitability order.

title_review: Service So Bad it was almost funny
review_preview: Made these reservations a week ahead on the basis of the TripAdvisor reviews. Received a confirmation call of the reservation the day before and understood that they had two seatings and that dinner was expected to take 2 hours so that the table would be...
review_full: Made these reservations a week ahead on the basis of the TripAdvisor reviews. Received a confirmation call of the reservation the day before and understood that they had two seatings and that dinner was expected to take 2 hours so that the table would be ready for the next seating at 11pm. This is not uncommon for us and based on our past experience we expected that the service would be very efficient (as this is the way the restaurant can ensure that table turn). Well, not so in this case. First, it took us asking three different waiters to check us in and then it turned out there was a matre de‚Äô who was chatting with another customer and thus did not acknowledge us right away (almost five minutes have passed). Then, the three of us were shown to a very small table (one for two people) that had three place settings but only two chairs. So we waited for a third chair to be found and delivered. Once seated, we waited another 10 minutes to receive menus. Once we received menus things sped up a bit and we ordered a number of plates and they began coming out from the kitchen at a reasonable pace. We ordered an additional copa de cava and the server brought out an un opened bottle and lost control of the opening and the cork shot past us, hit the wall and shot back barely missing us. After the sushi course, a waiter came by (there were many different waiters) and started stacking up the soya and wasabi dishes but one of our group wanted another plate of sushi. The waiter then informed us that we needed to be leaving soon and implied that we should not order more. We pointed out that we had only been there for 1:20 minutes (and remember at least 15-20 of that was waiting for them to be ready for us).  We let the waiter know that we were unhappy about being told we have to leave soon when we had not received all of our plates! We finally had all our food (and it was all very good food) but were not offered a postre menu. We asked for one, waited for its delivery and then waited yet longer to be asked if we wanted dessert. By now it was 11:00 pm and there were several empty tables available but we declined dessert, asked for the check and paid a bit over 100EU for dinner for three. We left the restaurant at 11:20, still what I think was a reasonable amount of time for a turn of the table, especially given the amount of time we waited for service. I have never had the experience of a server telling me in the middle of a meal that I needed to get ready to leave!  All of this is unfortunate because the food was very good. I would love to have this place on a return list the next time we are in Madrid but the service experience was so bad we will pass.

review_preview: I'd walked about a mile having arrived on a Sunday in a desolate food wasteland.Skipping the alcohol, I'd had some sort of local lemon drink and having asked, "You're famous for the ham but there's this grilled cut 'Secreto'. If I only eat here...
review_full: I'd walked about a mile having arrived on a Sunday in a desolate food wasteland. Skipping the alcohol, I'd had some sort of local lemon drink and having asked, "You're famous for the ham but there's this grilled cut 'Secreto'. If I only eat here once, which do I chose?" I went with the advice and the Secreto was just perfect - very simply cooked with salt crystals (ok plus some anonymous fries). I followed with caramelised toast and ice cream (mmm) and decent coffee - touched ‚Ç¨30. So I might just have been in the moment but I really, really enjoyed the simple experience. There's much more to the menu and I'd love to go back. Note it's a 'chain' (of 5), the place - fine, nothing remarkable but you're here for the food!

Although this never shows up in guides it may be a blessing because it is not overrun and it truly a must.

review_preview: A friend recommended this  restaurant and we were lucky to get a table at short notice. The small dining room was buzzing in anticipation as the platters of yummy food came out. The food is a fusion of Peruvian, Japanese and Astern and we chose...
review_full: A friend recommended this restaurant and we were lucky to get a table at short notice. The small dining room was buzzing in anticipation as the platters of yummy food came out. The food is a fusion of Peruvian, Japanese and Astern and we chose accordingly: a ceviche which was more sashimi as the tiger's milk is only poured on at the last minute (I prefer mine marinated for 10-15, especially when the fish is quite chunky), followed by various sushi dishes, including spider crab Californian rolls and couple of others, all exquisitely garnished and presented; and finally a Kebab gyozas with minced spicy pepper and cilantro. By this time we were full, so no dessert. With a fine bottle of wine the meal only came to Euros 75 which we felt was excellent value for money

We were inside with the aircon but there's a nice section on the street as well. Warning - lunch is not available when they say it is! Kitchen actually opened 30 mins after what was stated on the menu in the street.  Happy to recommend this restaurant to anyone in the Salamanca area.

review_preview: Using guidebooks and TripAdvisor we went to Cinco Jotas Serrano hoping to get a table. We were having a three night city Break before getting he train to Valencia for another few days. We just managed to get a table, possibly the last one! We...
review_full: Using guidebooks and TripAdvisor we went to Cinco Jotas Serrano hoping to get a table. We were having a three night city Break before getting he train to Valencia for another few days. We just managed to get a table, possibly the last one! We sat outside, lovely! This was some of the best food we have had anywhere in Spain; and we have been coming for the last 35 years. Sharing plates were exceptional, Sardine salad, Ham Croquettes, Calamari all great. The mains of Blue fin Tuna and steak with Pedro Ximenez sauce was brilliant. Very good value for money, we booked again or the next night, just as good, the Hake with Clams was as perfect a fish dish as you could wish for. Very few tourists, lots of locals who know a great restaurant when they see it. Staff were lovely. Go therefore you are ever in Madrid.

title_review: Fine dinning prices with tiny portions of average food
review_preview: We were looking for a medium price range restaurant near our hotel and had accidentally came to Cinco Jotas. Food: As soon as we were seated, we were served with 2 pieces of mini size of crispy potatoes (on the house, we guessed) and 2...
review_full: We were looking for a medium price range restaurant near our hotel and had accidentally came to Cinco Jotas.  Food: As soon as we were seated, we were served with 2 pieces of mini size of crispy potatoes (on the house, we guessed) and 2 very small pieces of breads. We ordered 2 portions of salads with monkfish for starters, a sirloin steak and grilled scallops for the mains, a bottle of water and a large glass of house red. The salad and pickle monkfish was a disappointment. The monkfish tasted bland, the whole dish was too watery and the texture of avocado, mango and the pickle monkfish just didn't married well with each other. The sirloin steak was hilarious. I ordered a steak but it arrived in 3 pieces of mini thumb size of meat. It also came with some baby potatoes instead of french fries (as described on the menu). It tasted not bad but it's like a tapas instead of a main course. The grilled scallops was the joke of the day. They sliced each scallop into half and made it look like serving with 4 scallops. The whole portion (with rice) was less than 1/3 of the plate. When I showed the picture to my friends, they thought it was a tapas instead of a main cause because the portion was tiny! Service: The staff was attentive, as he tried hard to persuade us to order more throughout our meal, which we reluctant to, especially after eating the starters and the mains and we decided not to throw more money into the sea. I am surprised to see this restaurant is ranked so high up on Tripadvisor as this place was like a desert on the night we visited. We were the only customers in the restaurant throughout the meal. Price: All together, included service charge (I guess), came to 80 Euro. If we wanted to leave with full stomach, I believed it would cost 300 Euro or more. Overall, the foods didn't tasted too bad but they weren't outstanding. The biggest issue for us were the portions and prices. The portions were the same as the fine dinning's but Cinco Jotas wasn't a fine dining restaurant. The price was expensive too. I had never been to a restaurant which was so stingy on breads. The large glass of house red was only served 1/4 of the glass. Every dish was in cute size. It cost us 80 Euro but we were still starving when we left and had to find another restaurant to fill up our stomach.

review_preview: Arrived in Madrid today and had dinner at Cinco Jotas. First time we have ever done a tour on our seventh or eighth trip to Europe and first visit to Spain. Visited Barcelona and Bilbao before Madrid. Frankly, have not been impressed with food, most...
review_full: Arrived in Madrid today and had dinner at Cinco Jotas. First time we have ever done a tour on our seventh or eighth trip to Europe and first visit to Spain. Visited Barcelona and Bilbao before Madrid. Frankly, have not been impressed with food, most of our own choosing. That all changed at today in Segovia and then at Cinco Jotas, a 15 minute walk from our hotel on the Paseo de la Castellano. Attractive decor and a relaxed, fun atmosphere. Mix of tourists and locals, but we were really too early for the local trade. Wonderful tapas to start the evening - seafood croquetas, jambon, frittata - followed by small, delicious tenderloin and potatoes. Service was great for a largish group around 35. Had a great time and would return.

They serve high quality food a bit from all over Spain, the presentation was very appealing, raw materials delicious. The selection of wines was wide and qualified (easy when in Spain, I must add). I was also pleased to find only Madrilenos eating there, which to me is a sign of quality. Reserving is probably advisable as the restaurant rooms just a few tables. Prices are average and you get a lot for your money in terms of food quality and culinary experience. Highly recommended!u

review_preview: They take their food seriously at Verdejo, a small, tastefully decorated restaurant just off busy Calle Alcala.On the day we visit for lunch, the place is packed (bookings are recommended), keeping the two waiters on the floor very busy. And yet, they have the...
review_full: They take their food seriously at Verdejo, a small, tastefully decorated restaurant just off busy Calle Alcala. On the day we visit for lunch, the place is packed (bookings are recommended), keeping the two waiters on the floor very busy. And yet, they have the time to explain the menu in detail, tell you about the ingredients used in the kitchen, and recommend the right wine for each dish. All without breaking a sweat. The menu changes with the seasons. In early Summer, we tried plump white asparagus from Navarra; home-made croquetas with egg, chicken and jamon; and a perfectly cooked rice with Spring vegetables, hare and foie. Each dish was perfectly cooked and expertly served. We discover later that the creative genius behind Verdejo is a woman called Marian Reguera, who has previously worked with some of the Spain's most innovative chefs. It shows: Verdejo is a winner.

review_full: ... they're plantains, not bananas. 10 green dots out of 5. We've travelled 7 countries in 5 months. Havana Blues might be the best restaurant we've been to in that time. It might be the best restaurant I've been to period. It's easily in the top 5. The Cuban Sandwich is perfect. The proprietor, Rafael, recommended an off menu appetizer with avocado and shrimp that was sublime. My buddy is a connoisseur of cheesecake, and proclaimed their guava cheesecake world class. It's the best cheesecake I've ever had. All that, and I haven't mentioned the people yet. Rafael is a tremendous host. It's obvious that he is a great boss, because all of the employees were in a great mood, and we went in on a slow Monday. They literally made us feel like family. If you don't eat here, you are doing yourself a disservice. Your life will be less for having missed it. Nuff said.

review_preview: I live in Madrid so I am usually unforgiving when it comes to criticizing local restaurants with too much hype. However, if there is one restaurant you should make an effort to find it (it's so discreet that it has become popular with Hollywood A-listers...
review_full: I live in Madrid so I am usually unforgiving when it comes to criticizing local restaurants with too much hype. However, if there is one restaurant you should make an effort to find it (it's so discreet that it has become popular with Hollywood A-listers who come to Madrid) it is El Lando. The decoration is wood panelling with high ceilings, the service is professional and experienced with Angel the owner greeting everyone with a smile. The walls are overflowing with photos of the likes of Tom Cruise, Will Smith, Halle Berry, Harrison Ford and even "Shinjan" (the japanese cartoon.. its late author was here). Food is home cook good, and they can cook everything to perfection whether it's eggs, beef, fish, etc. You won't regret anything you order. The only thing that might be a minus to this great restaurant is that it's lacking in space (seats are placed nearly back to back) and that reservations are very much in need. Otherwise if you want really good satisfying meal with an ambiance of old home cook restaurant, look no further.

title_review: Remind me never to eat here again...
review_preview: I came to this restaurant with high hopes, having read the reviews. I couldn't have been more disappointed, though. We ordered Tom Ka soup and a beef salad to start. The soup was served luke-warm, and lacked typical Thai ingredients most of the veggies there...
review_full: I came to this restaurant with high hopes, having read the reviews. I couldn't have been more disappointed, though.  We ordered Tom Ka soup and a beef salad to start. The soup was served luke-warm, and lacked typical Thai ingredients most of the veggies there were onion and cherry tomatoes. The been salad wasn't bad, but maybe just because we were starving.  For mains, we got the Penang curry, and a red curry with duck. Both curries were also brought out not hot, at different times, after waiting about 30-40 minutes after we were done with the appetizers. When we pressed the waiter to heat them up, he returned after 2 minutes, making it very obvious that everything was reheated in the microwave.  As for the Penang curry: it was way, way too sweet (it's not supposed to be), and extremely greasy. How there was any oil in it at all is beyond my understanding. The beef was also dry, and the whole thing tasted like overly sweet nothingness.  The red curry with duck also was pretty flavorless, and very disappointing. I've spent nearly a month in Thailand, so it's not like I don't know what it's supposed to taste like. To be fair, the waiter was nice, but that doesn't make up for the fact that the food is bad. The owners should be embarrassed to serve such lame, re-heated food, especially given that the average dish on the menu will set you back 13-14 euros.

title_review: I wouldn't eat here again if you paid me to - overpriced food prepared in a microwave!
review_preview: I try not to write negative reviews, but we are still extremely upset by our experience at this restaurant that I had to share so that people who appreciate good thai food do not waste a night out in Madrid like we did. To start...
review_full: I try not to write negative reviews, but we are still extremely upset by our experience at this restaurant that I had to share so that people who appreciate good thai food do not waste a night out in Madrid like we did.  To start off, service was horrible - we arrived at 8pm, right when they open and there was only one couple there with us until at least 9pm. It took forever to get our appetizers and we only got our entrees at 9pm. I like sitting and enjoying a meal, and generally don't like when my food comes out too fast, but the wait was ridiculous.  We had the beef salad which was the only thing we enjoyed even though the veggies were a bit soggy. We also had the tom kha kai soup which arrived at room temperature! We were in shock! Clearly they were heating up a pot that had been left over from lunch (hopefully not before that). It clearly wasn't fresh and didn't even have authentic Thai ingredients (it had cherry tomatoes and sliced onions) and had maybe 3 slices of chicken. On top of that it was 8.50 euros for an appetizer size soup.  We waited another half an hour for our entrees (which were not served at the same time as each other, nor were the entrees of the couple next to us served together) and the massaman curry came out cold also! When I handed it to the server to heat up I realized the bowl it was served in was hot meaning that they were taking premade food and heating it in the microwave! Our suspicions were confirmed when our red duck curry came out unevenly heated. I have never EVER been served microwaved food at a restaurant, never mind at a Thai restaurant where every curry should be freshly made in the wok for the customer! I am a huge Thai food fan and can eat it for every meal. I also prepare it myself at home. We were so disgusted and nauseated while we were eating. We should have left but were starving at that point that we didn't think about it until afterwards. Both curries were extremely sweet and the massaman curry was floating in oil.  On top of that, the bill came to over 45 euros. In the Thai food world, at that price you should be getting fantastic value for your money. I honestly have no idea how this restaurant is rated so well. I have never in my life had such a TERRIBLE experience at a restaurant.

They take their jamon very seriously and the carver had left so I was not able to order the Iberico ham. This was disappointing as the table next to me must have arrived earlier and they had what looked to be a delicious plate of it. There was also a small book/pamphlet on the table describing their ham, where the pigs are raised, etc. I sat on the patio, ordered some sangria (delicious) and they offered delicious olives. I ordered a few tapas (pork meatballs, assorted cheeses with bread. The waiter was busy so the service a bit slow, but I was not in a hurry and he was very friendly with a big smile. I would return here, or to one of their other restaurants, if I am in the area again, but only if the carver is working as I want to try the ham!!

title_review: One of my favourites in Madrid!
review_preview: I love everything about Bambubox: the decor is so understated, the ambience is relaxed and you immediately feel welcomed and comfortable. There are only two waiting staff and then another one or two chefs in the kitchen, but the service isn‚Äôt slow. I was last...
review_full: I love everything about Bambubox: the decor is so understated, the ambience is relaxed and you immediately feel welcomed and comfortable. There are only two waiting staff and then another one or two chefs in the kitchen, but the service isn‚Äôt slow. I was last here in August and knew then I would be returning - and no doubt, I'll visit in the future! To start, we shared the Bambubox platter ‚Äì and it was just as good as I remembered. The mango salad in the centre is definitely one of my favourite things; it‚Äôs just so refreshing and perfect for cleansing the palate after the deep fried appetisers and chilli dipping sauce. We all ordered a main course and I can wholeheartedly recommend the Kapao Talay (mixed seafood with basil, pepper and chilli). The chicken with cashew nuts, was also really lovely. The chicken had definitely been marinated in soy and honey, as it had sweet, sticky glaze and sauce. And I also have to mention the Kung Pad Pang Kari instead. This was a yellow curry, packed full of langoustines and was absolutely beautiful. It was another mild dish, fragranced with coconut ‚Äì and I loved the sauce, which was quite thick but stuck to the rice nicely.  Once again, nothing could be faulted!

title_review: A delightful addition to the Thai Restaurants family
review_preview: Although the menu has few choices for a typical Thai restaurant it doesn't fail to satisfy. Comfortable and well located this restaurant will be always a great choice for a Thai place. The green papaya salad was a nice surprise to finally find in Madrid...
review_full: Although the menu has few choices for a typical Thai restaurant it doesn't fail to satisfy. Comfortable and well located this restaurant will be always a great choice for a Thai place. The green papaya salad was a nice surprise to finally find in Madrid after many years of carrots salad pushed as green papaya in other Thai places. If you are a spicy Thai fan don't hesitate to ask for your dishes to be spiced up. The one down thing which I am sure this will change in the future, the lack of wine and spirits list. review_full: We booked for Sunday lunch at El Lando and enjoyed our meal it is best to call ahead rather than drop in as it is a popular restaurant. The food is traditional, fresh and delicious. It isn't fussy which I love but if you want something more interesting rather than straightforward but wonderful perhaps go elsewhere.  We had sliced tomatoes (which were already on the table but we were asked if we would like them), tomato bread, chips and fried eggs, green asparagus (very good crisp served with salt and lemon), clams (touch salty for my liking) and garlic prawns, steak and complimentary petit fours. The steak for two was excellent and is a large portion you could easily share it between 3 people. The steak continues to cook at your table as it comes on a hot plate. When the plate cools you can ask for another one to continue cooking it. The garlic prawns were also a stand out juicy fresh and not overcooked.  If you're in the mood for traditional high quality food executed well this is the right place. The waiters were friendly and there is an English menu.

Oh my gosh they were all delicious! I must have said "suculento" like a hundred times. The steak was definitely one of the best quality meat and cooking I've ever had in my life. We also got two desserts - the cr√®me brulee and the carrot cake. These were also very nice, but certainly for me, the highlight of the meal was the steak. At the end, it came to about ‚Ç¨54 for the whole thing including a glass of wine and water and they were generous enough to give us a couple of shots of a delicious citrus fruit digestif with the compliments of the house with our bill. All in all not a cheap place, but well worth it in my opinion. I would definitely go again and recommend it to others.

They specialise in local dishes: jamon with the biggest, sweetest, freshest tomatoes we have ever had, lamb chops, baked asparagus, grilled prawns. We had excellent wines by the glass, very reasonably priced. Our evening was rounded off with a complimentary glass of homemade grappa served in ice. We would highly recommend a dinner there, mostly locals and well placed if you want to go on to a Flamenco show.

The food was simply devine - try the asparagus, the tomato and lettuce salad, DEFINITELY have the Special Steak of the house, try the small clams and the cheesecake dessert. Their house wine (red rioja) was the perfect balance of taste, and the beer was one of the best we ever tried. It was so good, we visited a second time too! But be careful to book in advance: the place is almost always fully booked!

review_preview: We were recommended this restaurant by a client of my husband who has a sister living in Madrid. Looking at the reviews on Trip Advisor they were really good and thought we would give it a go. We read that it is a very Spanish...
review_full: We were recommended this restaurant by a client of my husband who has a sister living in Madrid. Looking at the reviews on Trip Advisor they were really good and thought we would give it a go. We read that it is a very Spanish local restaurant and not much English is spoken. Which...is true! Already on our table when we sat down was a platter of lovely looking tomatoes in olive oil which looked delicious and then they brought over a plate of tomato soaked bread in oil and garlic. We tucked in and it was delicious - it took AGES for them to come and take even our drinks order. I wanted a glass of Sangria but they would only do a jug so we ordered the jug which was fine - really good Sangria.  Our waiter then started speaking Spanish to us which we didn't understand but we soon found out that he was asking us whether we wanted any ham. He put down a plate of cured ham and then left again - so, we started tucking in - it was great. We eventually ordered our main courses and we said how we were glad that actually they hadn't come over earlier and we had ordered starters as they were giving us so much food at our table!! We ordered the chips and eggs which others had recommended and it was great but we received it before our main courses. We then received our meat dish which came with another side of plain chips and it was all just so dry!!! I had escalope and my husband had lamp chops. A Spanish couple on the next table had an amazing sizzling steak which looked and smelt really good which they shared between themselves and another two tables also had the steak! The downside of not being able to speak Spanish I guess! I was so full up by the time we finished our meals so we didn't have dessert and just got the bill. To my absolute shock and horror they had charged us for the tomatoes, the tomato bread and the plate of ham. The tomatoes were 3 EUR, the bread 6 EUR and wait for it....the ham was 24 EUR!! It was literally a plate of the same cured ham (not a selection of meats) so our bill came to 110 EUR! I was so angry but I had to let it go as I couldn't argue in Spanish. I have never been to a restaurant where they give you appetizer food and made you pay for it. It really made me think whether they charged the Spanish for it as they knew we were tourists. Don't get my wrong - I don't expect everyone to speak English in their own country but equally, help us out a little! So disappointed by this place...be careful what you order and make sure you speak Spanish!

title_review: El Lando: One of our best meals in Madrid
review_preview: We thoroughly enjoyed our experience in El Lando primarily because of their Chuleton. At 46 euros, it stands out as one of the costliest  items on the menu but man was it money well spent!We suggest skipping the usual bread and other appetizers that...
review_full: We thoroughly enjoyed our experience in El Lando primarily because of their Chuleton. At 46 euros, it stands out as one of the costliest items on the menu but man was it money well spent! We suggest skipping the usual bread and other appetizers that they push. Unless they outright say it's free, be prepared to pay for it.  The service crew though was very thorough and not at all imposing. Not all of them speak good English though but nonetheless all are equally competent. It will be a bit off strip, slightly far from the hustle and bustle of the plaza mayor And sol areas, but still very walkable.  And timing with mostly locals added a bit of comfort as me and my wife hate tourist traps. This is definitely not one. Highly recommended.

title_review: Fantastic food at a historic restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: I just returned from two weeks in Spain and ate at El Lando with my sister and a good friend who is a chef. El Lando was recommended to us by someone who is a native of Madrid. We were the only Americans - all...
review_full: I just returned from two weeks in Spain and ate at El Lando with my sister and a good friend who is a chef. El Lando was recommended to us by someone who is a native of Madrid. We were the only Americans - all locals. We arrived at 8:30 PM and the restaurant was empty and the waiters were dressing! Very funny. Still, they were so hospitable and set us up anyway. El Lando specializes in steak. EAT IT! It's delicious. Angel, the owner's son, was our waiter. He's so adorable. The house rioja is AMAZING. Drink it. Also popular is french fries with scrambled eggs. Tomato bread - yummy and great Serano ham. El Lando is very old and it's no nice to still have old world available in Madrid. The restaurant is a bit outside of the center of Madrid - like a 10 minute taxi ride. I highly recommend this restaurant. The food and service and ambiance were first class. Gracias Angel!

Thank you El Lando! will always be back.

title_review: The service was as good as the food - just can't get enough of this
review_preview: This is my fourth visit to El Lando but first with my wife, on vacation. Our wonderful partner company in Madrid brought me here for a lunch a few times hence I wanted to show my wife what I talked about. Without a reservation, we...
review_full: This is my fourth visit to El Lando but first with my wife, on vacation. Our wonderful partner company in Madrid brought me here for a lunch a few times hence I wanted to show my wife what I talked about. Without a reservation, we arrived a little early (13:10) then were offered to sit outside for 10mins., a couple glass of cava came with a tapas while waiting, then admitted to a table as the first guest for the lunch of the day. Meal was exceptional as always, with Jamon Iberico, fries with eggs, tomato salad and meat (sirloin for me, tartare steak for wife) with a bottle of Proto Ribera del Duero. It was the service, however, that was as good as the meal and impressed us the most, despite that we just spoke no Spanish. I may be wrong, but I think the gentleman who was preparing tables and chairs when we arrived was Mr. Lucio, the owner, and the cavas nor tapas were not charged when the bill came in. This truly is a wonderful restaurant, and we will be sure to come back. With a reservation.

review_full: We did a familiar dinner at this classic Spanish restaurant near Palacio Real in Madrid. First they bring you a tray with wonderful heirloom tomatoes and plates with Serrano ham (Iberico). We ordered 3 kinds of meat: grilled prime rib, entrec√¥te and tenderloin. All were delicious. As side dishes they brought fries and padron pimientos. They also brought "huevos rotos con patatas" (fried eggs with potatoes). Everything was delicious. As dessert, they brought small pastries and at the end they brought 3 kinds of orujo (digestive alcoholic drink made with herbs). A really fine dinner !

We got there the minute they opened and the place was nearly empty. Within fifteen minutes, it was literally packed. All meals apparently begin with fresh thinly-sliced tomatoes in olive oil. We placed these on pieces of fresh-baked bread that were covered with a thin layer of tomato-garlic pur√©e, onto which we added olive-oil soaked iberico. Sounds simple, but this starter was foodgasmic, especially when combined with the 2007 Valbuena (canNOT recommend this wine highly enough). We proceeded to devour delicious razor clams, then to entrees of steak and sea bass. Mind blowing. We ordered flan for dessert which was preceded by scrumptious complimentary sweets and a liqueur made from grape skins and various herbs. This was one of the best meals I have ever had in my life. I would go back in a heartbeat. 11 out of 10.

title_review: Refreshingly traditional. Good quality together with nice atmosphere.
review_preview: This restaurant is very pleasant and welcoming. The traditional decor is pleasing,  the service is excellent and very friendly and the food is traditional but good. Free of pretensions, we enjoyed dishes that are often sloppily made in other venues. A delicious tomato salad and...
review_full: This restaurant is very pleasant and welcoming. The traditional decor is pleasing, the service is excellent and very friendly and the food is traditional but good. Free of pretensions, we enjoyed dishes that are often sloppily made in other venues. A delicious tomato salad and tomato bread was awaiting us. The jamon was very good, the tripe (my Spanish husband's favourite) was near perfect and the steak unbeatable. An excellent house Rioja was recommended by the waiter and I appreciated the lack of pressure to choose an expensive wine, something that is becoming more and more frequent. We didn't order dessert, but were given a nice selection of sweets and a post prandial drink on the house! Price quality ratio very good. We will be back next time we are in Madrid. Refreshing and reassuring to find such a place!

review_preview: After reading good reviews about this restaurant, my husband and I decided to have lunch during our visit to Madrid.The restaurant is small and had nothing in particular about the decoration. It looks more like a fast food restaurant. Upon arrival, we were asked...
review_full: After reading good reviews about this restaurant, my husband and I decided to have lunch during our visit to Madrid. The restaurant is small and had nothing in particular about the decoration. It looks more like a fast food restaurant. Upon arrival, we were asked whether we needed Spanish or English menu. We responded Spanish. Two minutes later, a waiter who did not speak Spanish made an effort to understand our Spanish. He later made a mistake with the wine, which he had previously opened at the bar, before showing it to us for confirmation (this was something you do not usually see at restaurants, moreover when you order a bottle of wine). He brought the correct one order afterwards, but one more time, opening it at the bar before bringing it to the table. We had questions about the dishes listed on the menu, which he was able to answer in a "Spanglish" way. We decided to speak in English to him, but he did not speak English very well, either. We order a starter sampling, which included 8 pieces of 4 different dishes, which were OK, nothing special about them (we had been to Bangkok and other Thai restaurants in the US). We also ordered a seafood dish, which included 8 pieces of seafood with red and green peppers, a little bit of cilantro, and it was served on a small bowl, so did the Pad Thai, which only included 2 shrimps and a little bit of egg. Yes, 2 shrimps. We did not realize about it until we searched through the noodles. In addition, the Pad Thai looked lit it was previously cooked, and heated before serving. We ordered it and it arrived about 2 minutes later. The flavors were average, and did not impress us. We told the person who billed us about the Pad Thai and the number of shrimps included, but he laughed and said he would comment this to the chef. In addition, the waiter never came back to the table to serve the wine. Another lady cleaned the table besides us after the customers finished having lunch, spraying a large amount of cleaning product on the table, which was not nice, as we were eating and trying to enjoy the wine. We mentioned this to her, but she did not say anything. The prices were high compared to the amount of food and/or quality/complexity of the meals served. Moreover, when you take into consideration that there are many options in the area, offering Spanish food such as octopus, gambas, and navajas at a much lower price. As being a Tripadvisor user, just checked it to find restaurants near where we were and that's how I found it, and decided to give it a try due to its punctuation/rating. I will not recommend this restaurant.

review_full: My Spanish colleague who recommended this restaurant also told me that it's a favourite with their royal family, and lo and behold we were sat next to Princess Elena, with accompanying paparazzi waiting outside when we left!! A very gentlemen's club like set up downstairs in a nice dining room. They leave plates of tomatoes and tomato bread on each table which i found a bit weird, but no one else seemed to. The ham and melon starter was as simple as could be, but the ingredients were outstanding and it was heavenly. Followed by a really cracking entrecote for me and my wife had a gorgeous Tortilla Espana. It was a very nice way to spend a Monday lunchtime. Accompanied by a cracking bottle of vino I would definitely recommend this place. Slightly off the tourist trail but not by much and worth tracking down I would say.

title_review: Delicious food - not to be missed if you love Thai food
review_preview: This Thai restaurant was within walking distance of our hotel which was located on Gran Via. We ordered the Kai Satay and then placed a second order of this appetizer since it was so delicious. This is the best chicken satay we have ever tasted...
review_full: This Thai restaurant was within walking distance of our hotel which was located on Gran Via. We ordered the Kai Satay and then placed a second order of this appetizer since it was so delicious. This is the best chicken satay we have ever tasted and we have eaten in lots of Thai restaurants including some in Thailand. The peanut sauce that came with it was equally yummy. The other dishes were also very well prepared. The sweet and sour prawn was very good too. They provided rice at no extra charge with the entrees. The mango sticky rice dessert was excellent too. Would definitely recommend this place to all lovers of Thai food.

title_review: Spanish style in dining and service
review_preview: I have dined here with a small group of colleagues. We were placed in a beautiful private room. Really loved the typical Spanish style in furniture, with the wood panels on the wall, that created a warm and welcoming atmosphere.Food was very good. I...
review_full: I have dined here with a small group of colleagues. We were placed in a beautiful private room. Really loved the typical Spanish style in furniture, with the wood panels on the wall, that created a warm and welcoming atmosphere. Food was very good. I won't say "amazingly great", as it probably lacked a bit in creativity; but everything was fresh and perfectly cooked (I personally had Jamon and tomato bread as a starter, and fish as a main course). The restaurant team was very caring, and showed a fantastic approach to service. That was a huge added value. We didn't choose the wine, as we followed our waiter's suggestion, so I'm not able to say how valuable the winelist can be; but I can say that the one that has been served to us, was one of the best I had in Spain. Worth a visit.

A good Rioja crianza came to 14 euros! The service was informal but excellent, and the evening was idyllic! I hope this place doesn't go downhill with age, but try it out as soon as possible! It isn't very big, so if you want a table I recommend reserving: Bambubox is popular with locals and visors alike!
